awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track M: Distributed Flexible Strain Sensors to Enable Proprioceptive Cochlear Implant Electrodes
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern minimally-invasive surgical techniques employ flexible and continuously deformable catheters, endoscopes, and electrodes to navigate the complex windings of human anatomy. However, these devices currently lack sensory feedback and can carry a significant risk of complications due to inadvertent surgical trauma. This convergence research project will combine multidisciplinary expertise to enable thin deformable medical instruments, including electrodes and catheters, which will detect their own deformation and synthesize clinically-meaningful interpretations of the data via a bio-inspired approach. This project narrows its focus to a single application: cochlear implants (CIs) to address hearing loss (HL), a widespread problem in our aging society, which is also a leading cause of dementia and depression. This research aims to improve outcomes and safety of CI surgery, help relieve the burden and costs of HL to patients, and advance the health and welfare of the American public. The systems and methods developed in this research can be applied to additional surgical procedures in the future to enable a positive impact for an even larger portion of the American public. 

The culmination of this research will be to realize a flexible thin-film distributed strain sensor array with accompanying machine learning models to extract clinically-meaningful data when paired with a CI electrode. The project follows a convergence research approach to incorporate multiple viewpoints and disciplines, considering the needs in the surgical field and the opportunities in engineering and design. Furthermore, the sensor system is designed to be seamlessly integrated into CIs without adding any extra bulk or stiffness to the implant, thus making the system interoperable with the traditional implants and techniques that surgeons have been using for years.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Surgeons rely heavily on tactile feedback and manual dexterity to navigate complex anatomical structures and perform delicate procedures. Many surgical interventions, particularly in microsurgery or minimally invasive techniques, lack visualization or other real-time feedback on instrument-tissue interactions. This limitation increases the risk of unintended trauma, procedural variability between surgeons, and suboptimal patient outcomes. Cochlear implantation is one such example, where electrode misplacement and insertion-related trauma can lead to residual hearing loss in 50% of patients. Accordingly, cochlear implant adoption is still very limited: less than 5% of eligible Americans. The Sixth Sense Surgical project (this project), a convergence research effort, addresses these challenges by integrating bio-inspired sensing technology into surgical instruments to enhance surgeon tactile perception and improve precision, starting with cochlear implantation.

During Phase I, our multidisciplinary team consisting of microsystems and machine learning engineers, physicians, and regulatory and commercialization experts conceived, developed, and prototyped a sensor system that integrates seamlessly with existing cochlear implants and surgeon workflows. A stretchable, high dynamic range distributed MEMS strain sensor detects changes in shape of the instrument  in real time, providing surgeons with enhanced perception during surgery. To interpret this sensor data, we developed ML models that enable extremely accurate detection of adverse surgical events such as tip foldover and scalar translocation, combined with position reconstruction accuracy 4 times better than typical plane-film x-ray. Additionally, the model accurately reconstructs cochlear forces 10X better than human tactile perception. 

Throughout this process, we conducted hands-on evaluations with leading neurotologists, refining both the sensor design and user interfaces based on direct surgeon feedback to accommodate typical surgeon workflows and allow for easy adoption. This culminated in cadaveric studies with the proposed system, where participating surgeons reported very high (4 or 5 out of 5) ease of use and low (1 or 2 out of 5) risk of surgical disruption. In parallel, we established partnerships with cochlear implant manufacturers and engaged with the FDA to define a regulatory roadmap that will accelerate commercialization.

The Sixth Sense Surgical system offers the potential to reduce cochlear trauma, improve surgical precision, and increase cochlear implant adoption by minimizing risks associated with the procedure. During Phase II, we plan to refine sensor manufacturing for clinical-grade production, perform hands-on validation with cochlear implant surgeons to demonstrate improvement in surgical technique in full cochlear implant surgeries, and drive commercialization of this novel technology through regulatory approval and industry partnerships. By augmenting surgical perception, this technology represents a new fundamental capability for medical instrumentation. The framework developed here has applications beyond cochlear implants, including robotic surgery and minimally invasive procedures.

The team has identified that the best way to support the commercialization of this technology is via a startup company that will centralize IP from the participating universities (Carnegie Mellon University, The University of Illinois at Urbana Champaign). Through discussion with medical device manufacturers, we have determined that the startup company will develop sensors and software, and partner with medical device companies to do device-specific (i.e. for cochlear implants) integration, which supports a B2B (business-to-business) model for sales of the component sensors and software licensing. We have assembled a Phase 2 team including an assortment of experts from multidisciplinary backgrounds representing multiple types of organizations including Clinical Practice (Center for Neurosciences, Allegheny Health Network, The Ohio State University Medical Center), Industry (Advanced Optronics, Inc.), Public and Private Academic Institutions (University of Illinois and Carnegie Mellon University) and Government Research Organizations (Lawrence Livermore National Lab). 

This work directly supports improved hearing outcomes, expands cochlear implant accessibility, and reduces healthcare costs associated with hearing loss. By enabling surgeons to "feel" their instruments in real time, we aim to enhance patient safety and long-term hearing preservation during cochlear implantation, and ultimately enhance the quality of life for patients undergoing a range of surgical interventions.

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2025
Modified by: Jay W Reddy

Image
  • A schematic image showing the use of the intraoperative guidance system in a surgical setting for cochlear implantation. The system collects real-time data during electrode insertion and displays it to the clinician via a software user interface with audible alerts.
